snippet.textDisplay:
My brother read me the hobbit when I was five and he was nine, and that's the age I read it to my kids, so I can see Stephen's point about her being ready for LOTR outright, but I still think he should start with it. The simpler language, shorter narrative, and whimsy are a good bridge from Harry Potter into LOTR.
And I love his memories of benign neglect of earlier parenting. My parents were strict, but never censored our reading, it didn't occur to them. My brother introduced me to Stephen King at 6. Great brother. I do remember when he broke his collar bone and was having trouble holding books I was reading Cujo out loud to him. When my mom came in the room and heard f bombs coming from her 11 year old daughters mouth I think it finally occurred to her to check out what these books were, but the horse was a very long way from the barn at that point. Then I made my own kids wait a year between Harry Potter 3 and 4 cause I wasn't sure they were ready for the darker tone!
snippet.textOriginal:
My brother read me the hobbit when I was five and he was nine, and that's the age I read it to my kids, so I can see Stephen's point  about her being ready for LOTR outright, but I still think he should start with it.    The simpler language, shorter narrative, and whimsy are a good bridge from Harry Potter into LOTR.  
And I love his memories of benign neglect of earlier parenting.   My parents were strict, but never censored our reading, it didn't occur to them.    My brother introduced me to Stephen King at 6.   Great brother.   I do remember when he broke his collar bone and was having trouble holding books I was reading Cujo out loud to him.   When my mom came in the room and heard f bombs coming from her 11 year old daughters mouth I think it finally occurred to her to check out what these books were, but the horse was a very long way from the barn at that point.     Then I made my own kids wait a year between Harry Potter 3 and 4 cause I wasn't sure they were ready for the darker tone!

snippet.textDisplay: It's worthwhile to read the Hobbit, since it sets up the story going into the Lord of the Rings, and we will encounter familiar names and learn their fates. That said, I don't think the Hobbit is nearly as exciting as the LotR. It is kinda 'meh', and wouldn't surprise me if someone would be discouraged from reading LotR afterwards based on their experiences with the Hobbit.
snippet.textOriginal: It's worthwhile to read the Hobbit, since it sets up the story going into the Lord of the Rings, and we will encounter familiar names and learn their fates. snippet.textDisplay:
The difference between "The Hobbit" and "The Lord of the Rings" is a simple one: The Hobbit is told as a fable, while the Lord of the Rings is intended as an Epic.
As a literary scholar Tolkien was well-versed in many different northern european myths and legends, and with the different ways those tales were presented. In his work you can see various different takes on these in both his fiction and non-fiction work, including his modern translation of Sir Gawain and the Green Knight.
In writing The Hobbit Tolkien was very much aiming for a classic fairy tale, updated for modern sensibilities (of the time.) It shares similarities to so many classic fairy tales and fables that were still popular at that time, like the works of Hans Christian Anderssen, both in the story being told and the playful, whimsical style in which it was written. That same playfulness can be seen in "Tom Bombadil" and even "Leaf by Niggle," as they are intended to fill the same world-building role as The Hobbit: easygoing, playful and light stories as told by bards and shared in nurseries.
The Silmarilion fills another role in Tolkien's universe: that of history and even religious text. The style changes to suit this, being at once both some of his dryest and, at times, most dreamy work, meandering between nigh-incomprehensible prose and simple, faux-nonfiction chronologies.
Then there's The Lord of the Rings, Tolkien's Beowulf. Working one's way through the tale it becomes clear that, by the time of writing it, Tolkien had a much stronger understanding of the cultures and world behind the tale than he had at the time of the much friendlier "The Hobbit," and this is made evident mostly by the details Tolkien chooses to focus on, emphasizing Frodo's own mindset and Hobbit culture through the details he chose to focus on throughout the story. Long stretches of dry history and location descriptions with details of meals (all things the hobbits revel in,) a lack of concern for the politics of regions but much time spent in discussing the histories of the families involved (because hobbits love geneology.) A focus, throughout the tale, on the plight of the hobbit characters, not because they were the strongest, or even, truthfully, always the most relevant, but because the tale itself is an epic of, by, and for the hobbits, and not the other races, up to and including the aggrandizement of their contributions and attributes within the party.
All of Tolkien's work has both good and bad qualities. Unlike with most other authors, however, much of what is "bad" in Tolkien's work is intentional stylistic choice, limitations and shortcomings chosen because they are relevant to accurately matching the type and style of tale that he was wanting to tell in each volume, to the point that he, himself, throws shade at his own stories within others, implying that perhaps Bilbo's tale as told in The Hobbit is not entirely factual, which, if accurate, should imply that not everything as told in The Lord of the Rings is entirely to be believed either, told as it is from the viewpoint of a much more somber and, arguably, more typical hobbit, but nevertheless one who's goal in writing the story down was to share the legend, and the courage contained within, with later generations of his own people.
So . . . don't skip The Hobbit. Whether the maturity of the tale is as high as that of The Lord of the Rings or not really isn't the point. The story itself is fun, accessible, and reasonably short, all qualities that make it a worthwhile experience to delve into. Enjoy it as a simple fairy story, with dragons and adventure, and then, after reading The Lord of the Rings and The Silmarilion, come back to it, and read it again from a new perspective, that of one hobbit's account of events during a time of great trial in this large, fleshed-out world, and it just might allow you to appreciate its simplicity so much more.
snippet.textOriginal:
The difference between "The Hobbit" and "The Lord of the Rings" is a simple one: The Hobbit is told as a fable, while the Lord of the Rings is intended as an Epic.
As a literary scholar Tolkien was well-versed in many different northern european myths and legends, and with the different ways those tales were presented. In his work you can see various different takes on these in both his fiction and non-fiction work, including his modern translation of Sir Gawain and the Green Knight.
In writing The Hobbit Tolkien was very much aiming for a classic fairy tale, updated for modern sensibilities (of the time.) It shares similarities to so many classic fairy tales and fables that were still popular at that time, like the works of Hans Christian Anderssen, both in the story being told and the playful, whimsical style in which it was written. That same playfulness can be seen in "Tom Bombadil" and even "Leaf by Niggle," as they are intended to fill the same world-building role as The Hobbit: easygoing, playful and light stories as told by bards and shared in nurseries.
The Silmarilion fills another role in Tolkien's universe: that of history and even religious text. The style changes to suit this, being at once both some of his dryest and, at times, most dreamy work, meandering between nigh-incomprehensible prose and simple, faux-nonfiction chronologies.
Then there's The Lord of the Rings, Tolkien's Beowulf. Working one's way through the tale it becomes clear that, by the time of writing it, Tolkien had a much stronger understanding of the cultures and world behind the tale than he had at the time of the much friendlier "The Hobbit," and this is made evident mostly by the details Tolkien chooses to focus on, emphasizing Frodo's own mindset and Hobbit culture through the details he chose to focus on throughout the story. Long stretches of dry history and location descriptions with details of meals (all things the hobbits revel in,) a lack of concern for the politics of regions but much time spent in discussing the histories of the families involved (because hobbits love geneology.) A focus, throughout the tale, on the plight of the hobbit characters, not because they were the strongest, or even, truthfully, always the most relevant, but because the tale itself is an epic of, by, and for the hobbits, and not the other races, up to and including the aggrandizement of their contributions and attributes within the party.
All of Tolkien's work has both good and bad qualities. Unlike with most other authors, however, much of what is "bad" in Tolkien's work is intentional stylistic choice, limitations and shortcomings chosen because they are relevant to accurately matching the type and style of tale that he was wanting to tell in each volume, to the point that he, himself, throws shade at his own stories within others, implying that perhaps Bilbo's tale as told in The Hobbit is not entirely factual, which, if accurate, should imply that not everything as told in The Lord of the Rings is entirely to be believed either, told as it is from the viewpoint of a much more somber and, arguably, more typical hobbit, but nevertheless one who's goal in writing the story down was to share the legend, and the courage contained within, with later generations of his own people.
So . . . don't skip The Hobbit. Whether the maturity of the tale is as high as that of The Lord of the Rings or not really isn't the point. The story itself is fun, accessible, and reasonably short, all qualities that make it a worthwhile experience to delve into. Enjoy it as a simple fairy story, with dragons and adventure, and then, after reading The Lord of the Rings and The Silmarilion, come back to it, and read it again from a new perspective, that of one hobbit's account of events during a time of great trial in this large, fleshed-out world, and it just might allow you to appreciate its simplicity so much more.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm with Patton on The Hobbit. Start there. Frankly, I loved it and really couldn't get into the Rings - too much about war and shit - but the Hobbit was very warm and cozy (except the discovery of The Ring, and that trip through the caverns with Gollum was wonderfully eerie). Tolkien created this fantastic imaginary world in The Hobbit, but the Ring trilogy was too much like real life for me.
snippet.textOriginal: I'm with Patton on The Hobbit. Start there. Frankly, I loved it and really couldn't get into the Rings - too much about war and shit - but the Hobbit was very warm and cozy (except the discovery of The Ring, and that trip through the caverns with Gollum was wonderfully eerie). Tolkien created this fantastic imaginary world in The Hobbit, but the Ring trilogy was too much like real life for me.

snippet.textDisplay: The Hobbit was introduced to me by my Fifth Grade English Teacher, Father Taylor, Episcopalian (i.e. Catholic Light).  In a voice that was so sublime for Tolkien's works, he was a youth of London during the Blitz. You may scarcely imagine the impact his reading of that small, compact & complete tale was as heroin for my ears & imagination! While many more tomes of this work may be held in higher regard, this is still a nearly perfect gateway into Middle Earth for many younger folk....

snippet.textDisplay: I can relate to his comment on parental neglect in the 70s. Back then your parents gave you money to go stay all afternoon at the theatre and watch triple features with a cartoon, a war film and the opportunity to see Susan Sarandon fall off the wing of a plane while Robert Redford beat a burning pilot to death in ''The Great Waldo Pepper'. God bless her, my mom once took my brother and me, roughly ages 7 and 9 out to an evening show and she said, you go in that theater and I''m going to this one for the grownups. If you finish first, wait for me in the lobby. She went to see 'Mahogany' with Diana Ross. We thought we were going to see a Disney movie. Instead, we wound up watching' Papillon', a grim prison break story with Dustin Hoffman and Steve McQueen. Needless to say, she got an earful that night. :)
snippet.textOriginal: I can relate to his comment on parental neglect in the 70s. Back then your parents gave you money to go stay all afternoon at the theatre and watch triple features with a cartoon, a war film and the opportunity to see Susan Sarandon fall off the wing of a plane while Robert Redford beat a burning pilot to death in ''The Great Waldo Pepper'. God bless her, my mom once took my brother and me, roughly ages 7 and 9 out to an evening show and she said, you go in that theater and I''m going to this one for the grownups. If you finish first, wait for me in the lobby. She went to see 'Mahogany' with Diana Ross. We thought we were going to see a Disney movie. Instead, we wound up watching' Papillon', a grim prison break story with Dustin Hoffman and Steve McQueen. Needless to say, she got an earful that night. :)
